### Current Exhibitions

## Stephen Antonakos: Proscenium  
On view now

Named for a type of Greek stage, _Proscenium_ — created in 2000 by light artist Stephen Antonakos — animates the vast, darkened space of the Museum’s Theater Gallery with vibrant, saturated color, glowing light, and calligraphic line.

Antonakos (1926–2013) was a pioneer in the use of neon as a fine art. In a career that spanned over five decades, he created illuminated works for indoor rooms and outdoor spaces around the world including the United States, Greece, Japan, Germany, France, and Israel. As the artist observed, “For me neon is not aggressive, but it has certain powers. I simply thought so much more could be done with it abstractly than with words and images. I had a feeling that it could connect with people in real, immediate, kinetic, and spatial ways.”

Antonakos’s neon installations are classic studies in light, space, and form. Using a simple, minimal vocabulary of straight and undulating lines and incomplete circles and squares, his luminous environments are both tangible and transcendent. According to Antonakos, “Visual experience is inner experience. What I hope to do is offer access to a more intense, heightened kind of experience. One that is more conscious, more open.” Of course, the essence of this experience is light, which from time immemorial has been associated with spiritual...

**This ‘Report Accessibility Barriers’ form is for reporting Accessibility issues related to the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).**

* * *

**If you are an employee requesting a reasonable accommodation** , please contact Ricardo Espinales at [(914) 251-6086](tel:) or email [ricardo.espinales@purchase.edu](mailto:ricardo.espinales@purchase.edu) to discuss your request. The College’s Reasonable Accommodation Policy can be viewed on the [Human Resources Policies and Procedures page](/offices/hr/policies-and-procedures/). Human Resources will attempt to contact you as soon as reasonably possible, Monday – Friday during normal business hours. 

**To report a barrier that impacts many (examples below) and for which you don’t need an accommodation, please complete this form. You may complete this form anonymously.**

* * *

Your concerns will be addressed Monday – Friday during normal business hours. For emergencies contact the University Police Department at [(914) 251-6911](tel:914-251-6911). 

**Please use this form to report any ADA access barriers you encounter, either physical or electronic.** Examples include, but are not limited to, an inoperative elevator or wheelchair lift, a bicycle blocking an access ramp, drifting snow, an inaccessible document or website, and inaccessible classroom technologies. The College will attempt remove barriers as quickly as possible.
